Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: A departmental meeting is approaching where preliminary data summaries are expected.
Story: I sat at my desk, laptop open, research notes scattered around me. The departmental meeting was in two hours, and I still hadn’t finished summarizing the preliminary data. My advisor’s email echoed in my mind: “We need clear, accurate findings for the meeting.” I knew how important it was to get this right—my reputation as a scientist depended on it. Just as I started typing, my phone buzzed. It was a message from my stepmom: “Can we talk? Dad’s been quiet lately, and I’m worried.” I felt a pang of guilt. I hadn’t checked in with them all week. As their step-child, I was supposed to be the one who noticed when things weren’t right, the one who asked if everything was okay at home. But now, the weight of both roles pressed down on me. I stared at the phone, then at my half-finished report, feeling the tension build inside me. I wanted to be there for my family, but I also couldn’t let my team down. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more right now.
